The Colorful Art Challenge

A1

ES: Owen y Plock son amigos. Hoy, ellos tienen un desafío divertido. Quieren hacer una pintura grande.

EN: Owen and Plock are friends. Today, they have a fun challenge. They want to make a big painting.

ES: La pintura necesita muchos colores. "¡Vamos a buscar colores!", dice Owen. Plock está listo para ayudar.

EN: The painting needs many colors. "Let's look for colors!" says Owen. Plock is ready to help.

ES: Primero, Plock ve una manzana roja. "¡Este color es rojo, Owen!", dice Plock. Owen pinta una manzana.

EN: First, Plock sees a red apple. "This color is red, Owen!" says Plock. Owen paints an apple.

ES: Luego, Owen mira el cielo azul. "¡El cielo es azul!", exclama Owen. Él usa el color azul para el cielo.

EN: Next, Owen looks at the blue sky. "The sky is blue!" exclaims Owen. He uses the color blue for the sky.

ES: Ellos ven mucho césped verde. "Ahora, el césped es verde", dice Plock. El dibujo tiene mucho color.

EN: They see a lot of green grass. "Now, the grass is green," says Plock. The drawing has a lot of color.

ES: Owen y Plock trabajan juntos. Ellos son un equipo. La pintura es casi completa.

EN: Owen and Plock work together. They are a team. The painting is almost complete.

ES: "¡Mira, Plock! Nuestra pintura es muy bonita", dice Owen. La pintura tiene muchos colores.

EN: Look, Plock! Our painting is very beautiful," says Owen. The painting has many colors.

ES: Owen y Plock están muy felices. Ellos aprenden sobre los colores. ¡El arte es divertido con amigos!

EN: Owen and Plock are very happy. They learn about colors. Art is fun with friends!

Vocabulary

desafío - challenge
arte - art
colores - colors
pintura - painting
manzana - apple
cielo - sky
césped - grass
amigos - friends
feliz - happy
bonita - beautiful
buscar - to look for
hacer - to make/to do

Grammar Note

In this story, we use two important verbs: 'ser' and 'estar'. 'Ser' describes permanent characteristics or identity (e.g., 'Owen y Plock son amigos' - Owen and Plock *are* friends; 'El cielo es azul' - The sky *is* blue). 'Estar' describes temporary states or locations (e.g., 'Plock está listo' - Plock *is* ready; 'Owen y Plock están muy felices' - Owen and Plock *are* very happy). Also, notice how adjectives like 'roja' (red) and 'verde' (green) agree with the noun's gender and number (e.g., 'manzana roja' for a red apple, 'césped verde' for green grass).
